awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Catalyst: UCF Intersectional Self-Assessment as Catalyst for STEM Faculty Equity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine the issue of STEM faculty members’ perceptions of the match between their own goals and workplace-related values (organizational stated goals and values). The importance of the project lies in the fact that women’s perceptions of departmental and institutional appreciation and recognition are critical to their job satisfaction and intent to stay, which can impact inclusive hiring and retention. Research has yet to determine the causes of perceived mismatches among women and faculty of color and their workplace goals and values, and how this relates to differing experiences in the nature of work and broader forms of support. Yet, the inclusion and success of women is vital to meeting the national science and engineering workforce needs of the future. Therefore, this project aims to innovatively address these issues by drawing from the approaches of organizational justice and authenticity. While proven in other contexts, these theoretical frameworks have yet to be applied to an academic, intersectional equity study. 

The primary goal for the UCF ADVANCE Catalyst project is to conduct research that will inform strategies for minimizing inequities by specifically identifying the root causes and associated programmatic solutions of intersectional inequities. More specifically, the project will adopt an intersectional perspective to examine STEM faculty members’ perceptions of issues related to departmental climate and perceived faculty “fit.” The project will draw from organizational justice and authenticity frameworks, aiming to obtain systematic quantitative survey data from all STEM faculty and qualitative data through focus groups with STEM faculty at UCF. Findings will measure faculty members’ perceptions of organizational authenticity and justice, determine if and how these perceptions vary intersectionally (i.e., by sex/gender, race/ethnicity, age, parental status, and first-generation status). These results will then be applied to actionable items for institutionalizing transparent practices that are intended to improve departmental culture, faculty satisfaction, and equality as embodied in a five-year STEM Faculty Equity Strategic Plan. Pilot programming will consist of departmental climate workshops that focus on open, equitable department dialogue to foster an inclusive climate. Additionally, STEM mentoring faculty communities will be held as a space to discuss the practices and goals being developed across departments, along with a mentoring community created to address needs identified through this project’s research. A Strategic Planning Working Group and STEM Equity Executive Leadership team will contribute to developing the strategic plan and overseeing the planning process, respectively. Findings will be shared with the ADVANCE community and others through a website, presentations, and peer-reviewed publications. 

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions. Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate. ADVANCE Catalyst awards provide support for institutional equity assessments and the development of five-year faculty equity strategic plans at an academic, non-profit institution of higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
UCF ADVANCE Catalyst aimed to complete research that would help to identify root causes and programmatic solutions for potential intersectional inequities faced at the institution, in order to then construct a five-year STEM equity strategic plan. We looked to determine possible practices to improve department culture, faculty satisfaction, and equality as based in 5 objectives:

  1. Measure STEM faculty members’ perceptions of organizational authenticity.
  2. Measure STEM faculty members’ perceptions of organizational justice.
  3. Determine if STEM faculty members’ perceptions of organizational authenticity and/or organizational justice vary across different groups.
  4. Pilot strategies based on findings from Objectives 1-3 and programs implemented through other NSF ADVANCE funded projects.
  5. Create a STEM Faculty Strategic Plan for the university based on findings (Objectives 1-3), evaluation of pilot strategies, and university strategic planning.

Our key outcomes include:

  1. Construction of a novel survey instrument: In order to address Objectives #1-3, the team constructed a novel survey to measure organizational justice, organizational authenticity, and intersectionality in higher educational institutions. Prior research had yet to integrate these frameworks, much less constructing an instrument to measure these outcomes, particularly with a connection back to departmental culture.
  2. Identifying UCF STEM faculty members’ concerns related to organizational authenticity and/or organizational justice: As based in the aforementioned survey instrument, along with qualitative interviews, our research uncovered nuanced explanations to help address issues related to department culture, faculty satisfaction, and equality, including: (1) perceived organizational inauthenticity (particularly related to HSI designation), (2) the need to bolster a sense of faculty agency, and (3) a focus on fostering a culture of help & trust to address concerns of competition and isolation. We explicate on the significance of these findings for advancing theory and programming below.
  3. Novel theoretical framework: Through the integration of organizational authenticity and organizational justice, we constructed a novel theoretical framework that we termed organizational well-being. The intent was to offer a concrete basis by which institutional representatives could help to determine their strengths and weakness in relation to diversity, equity, and inclusion.
  4. Pilot programming: As a core goal was to determine root causes, we took precautions to develop our pilot programming based on our research findings. As such, we collaborated with established ADVANCE and community-programming; by sharing our key findings and collaborating with established partners, we were able to hold unique, distinct workshops that integrated best practices with new pathways for addressing our institutional issues, including: (1) determining assets-based and value-driven departmental cultures [based in trust, resilience, and faculty agency; this includes translating the value of participation to faculty], and (2) fostering institutional change [via concrete practices for faculty meetings and strategic planning]. These two foci help to address departmental climate and faculty advocacy (#2 helps to address mentoring through empowerment practices)
  5. Networking and dissemination: Key outcomes also include dissemination and broader impact through presentations, ARC networking, connections with ADVANCE programs at WVU and U of Louisville, publications, and extending research (which also helps to extend mentoring)
  6. Strategic plan development: While a necessary outcome included the 5-year strategic plan, an exciting organic outcome derived from a synthesis of our pilot programming with our strategic planning. By collaborating with the Center for Trauma Resilient Communities, we were able to both update programming and the approach to our strategic plan. We believe that a trauma-based approach to strategic planning could greatly advance our approaches to including marginalized faculty in STEM and foster greater resilience in a holistic manner to better support retention. Accordingly, while developing our 5-year plan, we are also now taking into account that we are in the “planning and pre-engagement stage” of “catalyst training.” While we had planned on publicly unveiling our 5-year plan at the end of our grant, we are now explicitly and intentionally working to determine and empower advocates in their own right. We now hope that, based in our collaboration and training, that we can help others interested in such Catalyst strategic-planning to learn about this trauma and resilience-based strategic planning.
